title: A 90-week, Multi-center, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study in Patients With Mild Alzheimer's Disease (AD) to Investigate the Safety, Tolerability and Abeta-specific Antibody Response Following Repeated i.m. Injections of Adjuvanted CAD106
description_brief: This study will assess the safety, tolerability and Abeta-specific antibody response of repeated intra-muscular injections of adjuvanted CAD106 in patients with mild Alzheimer's Disease.
drug: CAD106 — active Aβ immunotherapeutic vaccine (Aβ1–6 peptide coupled to a Qβ virus‑like particle), adjuvanted; given intramuscularly in the described trial.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is an active immunotherapy (vaccine) designed to elicit Aβ‑specific antibodies and thus target amyloid‑β pathology with the goal of disease modification rather than symptomatic cognitive enhancement. citeturn0search6turn0search1

Act: Key trial details — repeated intramuscular injections of adjuvanted CAD106 in patients with mild AD in a 90‑week randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study; CAD106 has been described in trials as inducing Aβ‑specific IgG responses. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Reflect: Classification check — because CAD106 is a biologic vaccine that specifically targets Aβ pathology (active immunization), it fits the 'disease‑targeted biologic' category. This is supported by multiple Phase I/II reports and trial publications. No evidence in the description suggests the trial is a symptomatic cognitive enhancer or a neuropsychiatric‑symptom trial. citeturn0search3turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational product is CAD106, a second-generation active immunotherapy composed of multiple copies of the Aβ1–6 peptide coupled to a Qβ virus‑like particle designed to elicit Aβ‑specific antibodies and avoid Aβ‑specific T‑cell activation—i.e., it directly targets amyloid‑β pathology. citeturn0search7turn0search2

Act: Key extracted trial details and mechanisms — 90‑week, multicenter, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled Phase II study in mild AD with repeated intramuscular (i.m.) injections of adjuvanted CAD106; CAD106 has been shown to induce Aβ‑specific IgG responses in a substantial proportion of treated patients and showed PET evidence of target engagement in prior studies. These facts identify the intervention as a disease‑targeted biologic acting on amyloid‑β. citeturn0search0turn0search7turn0search3

Reflect: Classification check — CADRO category A) Amyloid beta is the most specific fit because the vaccine’s mechanism is to generate antibodies against Aβ (not to modulate tau, inflammation, synaptic receptors, metabolism, or perform diagnostics). The trial description and primary publications explicitly describe Aβ targeting and immunogenicity; there is no indication of a multi‑target mechanism or a non‑therapeutic/diagnostic aim, so 'A) Amyloid beta' is appropriate. citeturn0search6turn0search5
Web search results used (primary sources): PubMed/PMC Phase II CAD106 study describing 90‑week randomized trial, safety, tolerability and Aβ‑IgG responses. citeturn0search7
PubMed abstract of the 90‑week Phase IIb CAD106 study (safety/tolerability/immunogenicity). citeturn0search0
